content: my friend enola by rose williams simple as abc materials you can use any yarn and the appropriate size crochet hook for the blue wrap i used 2 skeins 500 yds worsted weight yarn and a size h hook stitches cluster - 3 double_crochet in space indicated increase cluster - cluster ch1 cluster in space indicated directions chain 4 slip_stitch in first chain to form a circle or you can do a magic_ring if you are familiar with that 1 chain 3 always counts as 1dc 2 double_crochet ch1 3dc cluster ch1 3dc cluster in circle turn 2 chain 3 2dc between 1st and 2nd double_crochet of previous row chain 1 increase cluster in next two ch1 spaces cluster between last two double_crochet of previous row turn 3 chain 3 cluster in each ch1 space ending with 1dc between last two double_crochet of previous row turn 4 chain 3 2 double_crochet in ch3 space of previous row cluster in each space ending with 3dc in space before last double_crochet of previous row turn 5 increase row chain 3 increase cluster in each space ending with 1 double_crochet between last two double_crochet of previous row turn 6 repeat row 4 regular row 7 repeat row 3 regular row now you can see a pattern forming the beginning of one round starts with a ch3 space and ends with a double_crochet between the last two double_crochet of the previous row the next begins with ch3 2dc in the space created by the last double_crochet of the previous row and ends with cluster in ch3 space of previous row from now on be sure to maintain this pattern along the edge 8 increase row increasing in every other space turn 9 12 work 4 regular row by repeating row 3 and 4 with appropriate beginnings and endings 13 increase row increasing in every other space turn 14 17 work 4 regular row with appropriate beginnings and endings 18 increase row increasing in every third space turn 19 22 work 4 regular row with appropriate beginnings and endings 23 increase row increasing in every third space turn 24 31 work 8 regular row with appropriate beginnings and endings 32 increase row increasing in every fourth space turn 33 - 40 work 8 regular row with appropriate beginnings and endings 41 increase row increasing in every fourth space turn 42 - 49 work 8 regular row with appropriate beginnings and endings continue working in this manner until your shawl is as big as you want you can leave the edge as is or add any decorative edging or fringe be creative and enjoy below are pictures showing how the row develop
